label: A_tP4_129_ac-001
title: $\beta$-Np ($A_{d}$) Structure
comments:
Neptunium is found in three forms (Donohue, 1974): \begin{itemize} \item The ground state, \href{current_web_home_dir/A_oP8_62_2c-001}{$\alpha$-Np ($A_{c}$)}, stable below 280$^\circ$C, \item \href{current_web_home_dir/A_tP4_129_ac-001}{$\beta$-Np ($A_{d}$)}, stable in the range 280-577$^\circ$C, (this structure) and \item \href{current_web_home_dir/A_cI2_229_a-001}{a body-centered cubic ($A2$)} structure above 577$^\circ$C. \end{itemize} ~ \vspace{-.25in} 
 When $z=1/2$ the atoms in this structure are in the \href{current_web_home_dir/AB_tP2_123_a_d-001}{$L1_{0}$ (CuAu)} or the \href{current_web_home_dir/A_tI2_139_a-001}{$A6$ (indium)} structure. This structure is identical to the \href{current_web_home_dir/AB_tP4_129_a_c-001}{$B10$ (PbO) structure}. Pearson's Handbook, along with the original papers, give the space group as $P42_{1}c$ \#113. However, as noted by Structure Reports 15, 121 (1951), the correct space group is $P4/nmm$ \#129. $P42_{1}c$ is a subgroup of $P4/nmm$.
